channel.title: Science : NPR
channel.description: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 NPR - For Personal Use Only

channel.itunes:summary: The latest health and science news. Updates on medicine, healthy living, nutrition, drugs, diet, and advances in science and technology. Subscribe to the Health & Science podcast. http://www.npr.org/sections/science/

item.title: Broad Institute Wins Big Battle Over CRISPR Gene-Editing Patent
item.description: February 15, 2017 - CRISPR technology is already worth billions of dollars, investors say. This ruling seems to affirm the biggest piece of the pie goes to the Broad, over patent rival University of California, Berkeley.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - CRISPR technology is already worth billions of dollars, investors say. This ruling seems to affirm the biggest piece of the pie goes to the Broad, over patent rival University of California, Berkeley. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/15/515459773/broad-institute-wins-big-battle-over-crispr-gene-editing-patent

item.title: For Food Manufacturers, 'Sell By' Labels May Have Reached Their Expiration Date
item.description: February 15, 2017 - Those "expiration" labels on packaged food may confuse consumers and dupe them into throwing good food in the trash. Two major food industry associations want to change that and are proposing reforms.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - Those "expiration" labels on packaged food may confuse consumers and dupe them into throwing good food in the trash. Two major food industry associations want to change that and are proposing reforms. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/15/515427797/food-companies-may-say-goodbye-to-sell-by-labels

item.title: Another Big Health Insurer Loosens Rules For Covering Addiction Treatment
item.description: February 15, 2017 - Doctors treating people addicted to opioids often need approval from insurers before giving drugs that ease withdrawal. The delay can be risky for patients. Insurers are starting to come around.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - Doctors treating people addicted to opioids often need approval from insurers before giving drugs that ease withdrawal. The delay can be risky for patients. Insurers are starting to come around. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/15/515239382/another-big-health-insurer-loosens-rules-for-covering-addiction-treatment

item.title: The Trump Presidency's Potential Impact On Climate Change
item.description: February 15, 2017 - ProPublica senior reporter Andrew Revkin discusses President Trump's possible cuts to the EPA, as well as the potential impact of pulling out of the Paris climate accord.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - ProPublica senior reporter Andrew Revkin discusses President Trump's possible cuts to the EPA, as well as the potential impact of pulling out of the Paris climate accord. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/15/515390569/the-trump-presidencys-potential-impact-on-climate-change

item.title: Space Poop Problem-Solvers Take Home Cash Prizes From NASA
item.description: February 15, 2017 - NASA was looking for help from the public in solving a very specific challenge: How to deal with poop in a spacesuit. The winners included doctors, a dentist, a product designer and an engineer.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - NASA was looking for help from the public in solving a very specific challenge: How to deal with poop in a spacesuit. The winners included doctors, a dentist, a product designer and an engineer. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/15/515261463/space-poop-problem-solvers-take-home-cash-prizes-from-nasa

item.title: Feeling Way More Stressed Out? You're Not Alone
item.description: February 15, 2017 - A January poll finds that people's stress levels have spiked since August, with two-thirds of people saying they're worried about the future of the nation.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - A January poll finds that people's stress levels have spiked since August, with two-thirds of people saying they're worried about the future of the nation. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/15/515366975/feeling-way-more-stressed-out-youre-not-alone

item.title: Oroville Dam Evacuations Lifted As Officials Say Structure Can Withstand Next Storm
item.description: February 15, 2017 - People who live downstream of the Northern California dam were allowed to return to their homes more than two days after the structure's concrete spillways suffered serious water damage.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - People who live downstream of the Northern California dam were allowed to return to their homes more than two days after the structure's concrete spillways suffered serious water damage. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/15/515373815/oroville-dam-evacuations-lifted-as-officials-say-structure-can-withstand-next-st

item.title: Researchers Examine Race Factor In Car Crashes Involving Pedestrians
item.description: February 15, 2017 - Cars are less likely to stop when people of color step into intersections, a study says. That may partly explain why there are higher levels of pedestrian deaths among racial minority communities.
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - Cars are less likely to stop when people of color step into intersections, a study says. That may partly explain why there are higher levels of pedestrian deaths among racial minority communities. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/15/515336658/researchers-examine-race-factor-in-car-crashes-involving-pedestrians

item.title: Don't Think Your Bias Can Boss You Around? David Byrne Says Think Again
item.description: February 15, 2017 - The musician and multimedia artist has co-created an immersive experience designed to make people aware of their implicit biases. It's called "The Institute Presents: Neurosociety."
item.itunes:summary: February 15, 2017 - The musician and multimedia artist has co-created an immersive experience designed to make people aware of their implicit biases. It's called "The Institute Presents: Neurosociety." http://www.npr.org/2017/02/15/515221503/dont-think-your-bias-can-boss-you-around-david-byrne-says-think-again

item.title: Scientific Panel Says Editing Heritable Human Genes Could Be OK In The Future
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The National Academy of Medicine and National Academy of Sciences say a long-standing taboo on editing human genes could be lifted — even if the changes can be carried through to future generations.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The National Academy of Medicine and National Academy of Sciences say a long-standing taboo on editing human genes could be lifted — even if the changes can be carried through to future generations. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/02/14/514580162/scientific-panel-says-editing-heritable-human-genes-could-be-ok-in-the-future

item.title: Iron Age Potters Carefully Recorded Earth's Magnetic Field — By Accident
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The planet's magnetic field is weakening. Scientists aren't sure why, but studying ancient jars could help them find out. The ceramics provide a remarkable window onto Earth's magnetic past.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The planet's magnetic field is weakening. Scientists aren't sure why, but studying ancient jars could help them find out. The ceramics provide a remarkable window onto Earth's magnetic past. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/14/515032512/iron-age-potters-carefully-recorded-earths-magnetic-field-by-accident

item.title: From Vector To Zoonotic: A Glossary For Infectious Diseases
item.description: February 14, 2017 - The world of infectious diseases has more than a few words and phrases you might want to know more about. We've got definitions for 11 key terms.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - The world of infectious diseases has more than a few words and phrases you might want to know more about. We've got definitions for 11 key terms. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/14/512875686/from-vector-to-zoonotic-a-glossary-for-infectious-diseases

item.title: Why Killer Viruses Are On The Rise
item.description: February 14, 2017 - If you think there are more dangerous infectious diseases than ever, you're right. One big reason: pushing animals like this one out of their homes.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - If you think there are more dangerous infectious diseases than ever, you're right. One big reason: pushing animals like this one out of their homes. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/14/511227050/why-killer-viruses-are-on-the-rise

item.title: Hookup Culture: The Unspoken Rules of Sex on College Campuses
item.description: February 14, 2017 - Research suggests that college students are not having more sex than their parents were a generation ago. But sociologist Lisa Wade says the culture around sex has changed dramatically.
item.itunes:summary: February 14, 2017 - Research suggests that college students are not having more sex than their parents were a generation ago. But sociologist Lisa Wade says the culture around sex has changed dramatically. http://www.npr.org/2017/02/14/514578429/hookup-culture-the-unspoken-rules-of-sex-on-college-campuses

item.title: 90 Percent Of Fish We Use For Fishmeal Could Be Used To Feed Humans Instead
item.description: February 13, 2017 - Currently, one-fourth of all fish caught globally goes to produce fishmeal and fish oil for farmed seafood, pigs and chickens. A lot of it is "food grade" and could be feeding the world's hungry.
item.itunes:summary: February 13, 2017 - Currently, one-fourth of all fish caught globally goes to produce fishmeal and fish oil for farmed seafood, pigs and chickens. A lot of it is "food grade" and could be feeding the world's hungry. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/13/515057834/90-percent-of-fish-we-use-for-fishmeal-could-be-used-to-feed-humans-instead
